questions.text: A patient comes to the dermatology clinic with the following lesions on his upper trunk, upper arm, and neck. He also complains of a mild itch and scaling over the lesions. Which of the following is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario and image shows characteristic lesions of pityriasis versicolor, presenting as scaly, discolored patches on the upper trunk and arms. This condition is caused by Malassezia species, most commonly M. globosa and occasionally M. furfur.

Pityriasis versicolor

  • It is a chronic, mild skin infection caused by Malassezia yeasts, characterized by scaly, discolored or depigmented patches.
  • It primarily affects the upper trunk; lesions may be discrete or confluent.

Pathophysiology:

  • Involves disruption in host-yeast balance.
  • Triggered by multiple, often unclear, factors.
  • Skin oils, UV exposure, and immune responses may play roles.
  • Some evidence of:
    • Increased lymphocyte response to mycelial antigens.
    • T-cell suppression due to yeast cell wall lipids.
  • Malassezia causes rare systemic infections in infants on lipid-rich IV therapy.

Causative Organisms:

  • Mostly caused by Malassezia globosa.
  • M. sympodialis and M. furfur may also be involved.

Clinical Features:

  • Presentation:
    • Patchy skin color changes with fine scaling.
    • Lesions: Sharply defined macules, sometimes red, mildly itchy.
    • Common areas: Upper trunk, neck, upper arms, abdomen.
    • Less commonly: Axillae, groin, thighs, genitalia, hands, popliteal fossae.
    • Scaling may be highlighted by stretching or tape test.
  • Variants:
    • Scalp and facial involvement are more common in tropics.
    • Palmar lesions are rare in temperate zones.
    • Rare: Anetoderma-like changes post-infection.
  • Color Variability:
    • Ranges from pale ochre to brown.
    • Lesions darker on untanned skin; paler on tanned or darker skin.
    • Depigmentation may persist post-treatment without scaling.
    • Under Wood's lamp: Pale yellow fluorescence; detects hidden lesions.

Candida (Option B): Candida is a type of yeast that causes candidiasis, also known as candidosis, moniliasis, or thrush. It is typically a secondary infection, most often seen in immunocompromised individuals. It can involve the oral cavity, vagina, penis, or other body sites.

Trichophyton rubrum (Option C): Trichophyton rubrum is an anthropophilic fungus and the most widespread dermatophyte in humans, commonly causing chronic infections of the skin and nails, and rarely the scalp. These features do not align with the clinical scenario described.

Trichophyton mentagrophytes (Option D): Trichophyton mentagrophytes is a zoophilic fungus known to cause inflammatory skin or scalp lesions, especially in rural workers and can lead to kerion of the scalp or beard, these features are not consistent with the condition described here.

questions.text: A sample from the skin lesions of a patient was seen under the microscope on a KOH mount. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a KOH preparation revealing the characteristic "spaghetti and meatballs" appearance of Malassezia, with short hyphae and round yeast cells. This microscopic pattern is typical of pityriasis versicolor.

  • Pityriasis versicolor is a chronic, mild skin infection caused by Malassezia yeasts.

Investigations:

  • Direct Microscopy:
    • Reveals coarse, short, septate mycelial filaments (2-5 μm wide, up to 25 μm long).
    • Presence of thick-walled, round to oval yeast cells (2-8 μm in diameter).
    • Diagnostic clue is the mycelial form, which may dominate the sample.
  • Classic Microscopic Appearance:
    • Often described as "spaghetti and meatballs" or "bananas and grapes" due to the mix of hyphae and yeast cells.
  • Culture Not Diagnostic:
    • Malassezia species are part of normal skin flora.
    • Hence, their growth in cultures from skin scrapings is not clinically significant and rarely performed in standard labs.
  • Advanced Techniques:
    • Molecular diagnostics (e.g., PCR) and MALDI-TOF MS are available for strain-level identification.
    • Mainly used in research settings, not routine diagnosis.

Tinea corporis (Option A): The KOH mount in this condition shows hyaline and septate hyphae unlike Malassezia.

Onychomycosis (Option B) also known as Tinea unguium is a nail infection commonly caused by fungi like Trichophyton rubrum and T.digitale. This is not the given scenario.

Candidiasis (Option D): Also known as candidosis, moniliasis, or thrush can involve the oral cavity, vagina, penis, or other body sites. Candida under microscopy with KOH shows non-pigmented septate hyphae with a characteristic dichotomous appearance.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with asymptomatic skin lesions on the upper back as in the image. Which of the following is given for the treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image shows the lesions of Pityriasis versicolor, which is treated using antifungal agents like ketoconazole. Pityriasis versicolor is caused by Malassezia, a dimorphic lipophilic fungus, also known as Pityrosporum. It is a component of normal skin flora.

Griseofulvin (Option B) is used primarily for dermatophyte infections of skin, nails, and hair, like tinea capitis, but not for P. versicolor.

Betamethasone (Option D) is a corticosteroid and is not used for the treatment of P. versicolor as it may worsen the condition.

questions.text: The microorganism associated with the condition given in the image is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows erythematous, scaly, yellow patches on the scalp, consistent with seborrheic dermatitis, commonly associated with Malassezia species, particularly M. globosa and M. restricta.

Seborrheic dermatitis

  • Seborrheic dermatitis (SD) is an inflammatory skin disease in areas rich in sebaceous glands, particularly the scalp, face, and body folds.
  • Malassezia yeasts, particularly globosa and M. restricta, are the primary fungal agents implicated in SD and dandruff.
  • These yeasts are lipophilic and part of normal skin flora, especially in oily regions.

Pathogenesis :

  • Linked to the interplay of normal microscopic skin flora (especially Malassezia spp.)
  • The composition of lipids on the skin surface and individual susceptibility.
  • In addition to fungi, bacterial dysbiosis involving Staphylococcus, Pseudomonas, and Streptococcus may play a secondary role.

Clinical Features:

Common affected sites:

  • Face: Red or pink patches with fine scaling, especially in nasolabial folds, medial eyebrows, eyelids, glabella, perinasal area, ear creases and canals.
  • Scalp:
    • Mild cases: Dry, flaky white or grey scales (dandruff).
    • Severe cases: Greasy, yellowish, thick scales with redness and crusting known as Cradle cap, especially in infantile SD.
    • The beard area may show similar greasy, scaling patches.
  • Torso
  • Eyes
  • Genital Area: Vulvar involvement in women may coexist with facial or torso SD

Microsporum (Option A): The microsporum spp. causes tinea capitis (ringworm), especially in children. The lesions appear as follows:

Streptococcus (Option B) is a bacterium causing infections like sore throat, cellulitis, etc, but does not cause seborrheic dermatitis.

Corynebacterium (Option C) is a bacterium usually responsible for diphtheria and is not a causative agent of seborrheic dermatitis.

Reference: 

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6162526/
  2. https://www.adelaide.edu.au/mycology/fungal-descriptions-and-antifungal-susceptibility/dermatophytes/microsporum#microsporum-canis

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes a disease that presents as shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The condition shown is Black Piedra, also called Trichomycosis or Tinea nodosa. It is caused by Piedraia hortae and presents as hard, black nodules firmly attached to the scalp or body hairs.

Black piedra

  • It is also known as Trichomycosis nodosa or Tinea nodosa.
  • Clinical features include no symptoms and are characterised by firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules on the hairs of the scalp and, less commonly, in the beard, moustache, or pubic area.
  • Investigations:
    • On KOH mount, the nodules have closely packed brown hyphae in a viscous or cement-like substance.
    • Trichoscopy shows small brown black nodules around the hair shafts. (Confirms diagnosis)
    • Culture colony: Slow growing, domed, compact and black.
  • Treatment:
    • Shaving or cutting the hair.
    • Antifungal preparations like benzoic acid ointment compound BP are used for preventing recurrence.
    • Terbinafine is also used.

Trichosporon (Option B): This yeast colonises the skin, GIT, and respiratory tract and can cause white piedra, which affects the hair shafts. The nodules formed here are soft, white, grey or brown.

Corynebacterium (Option C) is found to improve the growth of Trichosporon spp. that causes white piedra; however, it does not cause black piedra as in the image.

Trichophyton tonsurans (Option D): This causes Tinea capitis, also known as ringworm or herpes tonsurans. This can cause non-inflammatory or inflammatory lesions (keroin). Keroin presents with permanent alopecia and pus discharge.

Reference: 

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482477/

questions.text: What is the causative organism of this asymptomatic lesion on the palm?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows Tinea nigra, a superficial fungal infection caused by Hortaea werneckii. It typically presents as a painless, dark brown to black, non-scaly macule on the palms.

Tinea nigra

  • Tinea nigra is characterized by the presence of a painless brown-to-black macule. The macule appears insidiously as a small dark spot.
  • The lesion is sharply demarcated and non-scaly, usually found in the skin of the palms.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • The hyphae of Hortaea wernecki present in the stratum corneum lead to its thickening.
  • Clinical features:
    • Asymptomatic
    • Macular, sharply demarcated, and non-scaly lesions.
    • Affects palms>> soles, and rarely neck and trunk.
  • Management:
    • First line: Topical azoles (ketoconazole and econazole).
    • Other fungicidal preparations like butenafine, benzoic acid compound ointment.

Malassezia globosa (Option A) causes Pityriasis versicolor, which presents with scaly, discoloured or depigmented lesions on the skin. This is not similar to the given scenario.

Trichosporon spp. (Option C) causes white piedra, which presents with soft, white, grey or brown superficial nodules on the hair shafts.

Piedraia hortae (Option D) causes black piedra, which presents with firmly adherent, black, gritty, and hard nodules commonly on the scalp hair and less commonly on the beard, moustache, and pubic region.

questions.text: Besnier's sign is a clinical test described in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Besnier's sign is seen in pityriasis versicolor, which refers to the indistinct scales of the macules being accentuated by scratching with a fingernail.


Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3505421/

questions.text: What is the management for a patient who comes with the following presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image is consistent with oral candidiasis, commonly seen in immunosuppressed individuals. It is typically caused by Candida species and managed with topical or systemic antifungals depending on patient age and immune status.

  • The condition is generally secondary to immune suppression, which can be local or systemic, including extremes of age (newborns and elderly), immunocompromising diseases such as HIV/AIDS, and chronic systemic steroid and antibiotic use.

Management:

  • In Infants (Oral Thrush): Nystatin, amphotericin B, or miconazole gel is used topically multiple times a day.
  • In Adults:
    • Denture hygiene and removal at night are essential.
    • Topical therapies like lozenges or oral suspensions of nystatin, amphotericin, or miconazole work well for acute oral infections.
    • Treatment duration: Typically 10-14 days.
  • Chronic or Refractory Cases:
    • Fluconazole or itraconazole is more effective when topical therapy fails.
    • Alternative agents: Voriconazole or posaconazole.
    • Oral biopsy may be needed to rule out leukoplakia in persistent cases.
  • Management in Immunosuppressed Patients
    • Topical treatments often fail; systemic agents are preferred.
    • Short courses of fluconazole or itraconazole are recommended to prevent resistance.
    • Itraconazole solution or newer formulations like Lozanoc offer better absorption.
    • Voriconazole or posaconazole serve as alternatives for resistant or recurrent infections.

Vitamin supplements (Option A): Even though vitamin D3 has shown potential in preventing the formation of Candida biofilms, which are known to resist antifungal treatments due to their unique structural characteristics, only giving vitamin supplements will not cure oral candidiasis.

Biopsy for carcinoma (Option C) is done only in suspected cases and is not a first-line method of treatment.

Dapsone plus steroids (Option D) is not preferred in candidiasis as dapsone has an antimicrobial effect used for leprosy and dermatitis herpetiformis, but is ineffective here. Steroids are known risk factors for candidiasis and hence are not used.

Reference:

  • https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10874479/#:~:text=Since%20Candida%20biofilm%20is%20resistant,of%20virulence%20genes%20in%20C.

questions.text: Topical antifungal therapy is the first-line therapy for uncomplicated cases of oral candidiasis. A patient on immunosuppressives develops white lesions on the tongue that cannot be rubbed off. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A white lesion on the tongue that can't be wiped off in an immunocompromised patient, as given in the image, is oral hairy leukoplakia, caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).

Oral hairy leukoplakia

  • Oral hairy leukoplakia is a white lesion typically seen on the sides of the tongue.
  • It develops gradually and often goes unnoticed in the early stages.
  • The surface may appear corrugated or "hairy", hence the name.

Cause & Mechanism:

  • Caused by reactivation of Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV).
  • EBV infects the mature upper epithelial layers, not the deeper basal layers.
  • The virus replicates in surface cells, leading to hyperkeratosis and characteristic white patches.

Risk Factors

  • HIV/AIDS is the most common underlying condition.
  • May also occur in:
    • Hematologic cancers (e.g., leukaemia, lymphoma)
    • Immunosuppressive therapy (e.g., post-transplant medications, biologics)
    • Inhaled corticosteroid use
    • Elderly individuals, even if immunocompetent

Clinical Features

  • White velvety or corrugated plaques on the lateral borders of the tongue.
  • Lesions are often bilateral, but can be unilateral.
  • In advanced cases, plaques can spread to involve the entire tongue or oropharynx.
  • Typically painless and non-removable by scraping.


Candida (Option A): Even though candidiasis can be seen in immunocompromised patients, the lesion of candidiasis is easily wiped off, revealing an erythematous appearance.

HSV (Option B) causes initial and repeated blistering episodes, mainly affecting the lips, mouth, and genital areas. This is not the given scenario.

HHV8 (Option D) is linked to the development of Kaposi sarcoma (especially in HIV), a vascular malignancy, as well as certain B-cell proliferative disorders like primary effusion lymphoma (PEL) and multicentric Castleman disease (MCD). This is not the cause of the given condition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old obese woman presents to the OPD with itching and burning sensations under her breasts and upper abdomen. On examination, the following is seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image showing erythematous, moist lesions with satellite pustules in the skin fold is characteristic of Candida intertrigo, making it the correct diagnosis.

Candida intertrigo

  • A fungal infection affecting skin folds, particularly in overweight individuals, is also referred to as flexural candidiasis.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Maceration (softening and whitening of skin) is seen in the toe or finger web spaces.
    • Moist surface with erosions or peeling skin.
    • Satellite lesions (small pustules or papules) may appear around the main patch.
    • Red, inflamed skin deep within folds (e.g., groin, under breasts, armpits).
    • Itching and burning are common symptoms, sometimes intense.
    • In interdigital areas, Candida often coexists with Gram-negative bacteria (e.g., in erosio interdigitalis blastomycetica).
    • Trigger factors include tight clothing, poor hygiene, warm, humid environments, occlusion by rings/dressings, and anatomical predispositions.
  • Management:
  • Topical Treatment
    • Use topical azole or polyene antifungals for at least 2 weeks.
    • May require longer therapy depending on response and severity.
    • Drying agents (e.g., powders) and keeping the area dry are critical to prevent recurrence.
    • Potassium permanganate soaks can help reduce excessive moisture and secondary bacterial infection.
    • Additional Measures:
      • Open footwear in foot infections.
      • Address bacterial co-infections if present.
      • Advise on weight loss, hygiene, and wearing breathable fabrics.

Tinea corporis (Option A), also known as ringworm, is a superficial fungal infection of the skin caused by dermatophytes such as Trichophyton, Microsporum, and Epidermophyton species. It usually affects non-hairy parts of the body and appears as circular, scaly patches with central clearing and a red, often elevated, outer edge.

Pyoderma (Option C) is a type of ulcerative skin condition classified under neutrophilic dermatoses, which presents as a painful skin ulcer characterised by tissue necrosis, with an irregular shape, violaceous discolouration, and undermined edges.

Flexural psoriasis (Option D), also known as inverse psoriasis or intertriginous psoriasis, is a type of plaque psoriasis that typically affects skin folds such as the underarms, genital area, and beneath the breasts. It presents with well-demarcated erythematous lesions, while intertrigo has moist, inflamed, peeling or eroded skin with satellite lesions.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male developed redness of the glans and radial fissuring of the prepuce 2 weeks ago. Which systemic illness should he be screened for?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a case of severe candidal balanoposthitis affecting the glans and prepuce, which is commonly seen in patients with underlying uncontrolled diabetes mellitus. Hence, it has to be evaluated.

  • Candida can colonize the glans penis, especially in uncircumcised males, without causing symptoms.
  • When balanitis due to Candida occurs, it is often linked to Candida overgrowth or infection in the sexual partner.

Clinical Features:

  • Mild form: Small papules or pustules appear a few hours post-intercourse and rupture, leaving peeling edges. These may resolve on their own.
  • Symptoms: Mild soreness and irritation; may present intermittently in some individuals.
  • Severe or chronic form: Persistent inflammation of the glans and foreskin. In hot climates, groin involvement may also occur.

Investigations:

  • Diagnosis is confirmed by isolating Candida (preferably in high amounts) from affected sites.
  • Even small numbers of Candida with classic symptoms warrant treatment.
  • Negative swabs do not rule out a diagnosis if not taken during the active stage.
  • Persistent or recurrent infections may indicate underlying diabetes, which should be evaluated.

Management:

  • Topical antifungals: First-line treatment, applied multiple times daily.
  • Partner treatment: Treat any source of reinfection in the sexual partner.
  • Diabetes management: Essential if present.
  • Couples therapy: In recurring cases, both partners should be treated simultaneously for a longer duration.

Tuberculosis (Option A) may rarely present with an ulcer on the dorsal glans or prepuce, swelling, nodules, or a fungating growth without urethral involvement (penile TB).

Systemic candidiasis  (Option C): This occurs as a result of an untreated candida infection. The lesions typically begin as asymptomatic or mildly itchy macules, papules, or nodules. They are usually distributed on the trunk and extremities and present as a characteristic maculopapular or nodular rash in the early phase of the infection.

Chronic renal failure (Option D) does not present with the given lesions.

questions.text: Dermatophytes primarily involve which layer of the skin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The invasion of dermatophytes begins with the outermost skin layer, the stratum corneum.

  • Dermatophytes include the fungi that cause ringworms or dermatophytosis. They include Microsporum, Trichophyton, and Epidermophyton.
  • The invasion of dermatophytes begins with the attachment of arthroconidia (infectious fungal elements) to the outermost skin layer, the stratum corneum.
  • Once attached, the fungi germinate and extend hyphae radially, moving outward from the point of origin.
  • Laboratory studies suggest that the underlying keratinocyte layers become indented as hyphae grow, likely due to the action of enzymes that degrade keratin.
  • Surface Sensitivity (Thigmotropism): Hyphae can detect and respond to changes in surface structure, guiding them to penetrate between corneocytes, enabling deeper tissue colonisation.

questions.text: A patient presents with itchy lesions as shown in the image. The causative organism is most likely to be:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows annular, scaly, and well-demarcated plaque of Tinea corporis, a superficial dermatophyte infection of the glabrous skin. It is most commonly caused by Trichophyton species.

Tinea corporis

  • Tinea corporis refers to a fungal infection (ringworm) of the non-hairy (glabrous) skin.
  • It affects the trunk and limbs, but not specialised areas like the scalp (tinea capitis), feet (tinea pedis), or groin (tinea cruris).
  • Caused by dermatophyte fungi that grow within the stratum corneum.
  • In some cases, terminal hair follicles in the affected area may also be invaded.

Clinical Features:

  • Typical Presentation
    • Commonly appears on exposed areas unless it spreads from other infected regions (e.g., scalp to neck/trunk, or groin to buttocks).
    • Lesions are:
      • Round to annular (ring-shaped)
      • Have sharply defined, raised, and often scaly borders
      • May be single or multiple and can merge to cover larger areas
  • Typically, less inflammatory than tinea capitis or tinea barbae.
  • Severe lesions may show:
    • Pustules, vesicles, or rarely bullae
    • Small pustules can be seen even in mild cases
  • Scaling is common but not always present.

Management:

  • Topical antifungals are first-line:
    • Terbinafine cream: Apply twice daily for 2 weeks
    • Azole creams (e.g., clotrimazole, miconazole): Apply once or twice daily for 2-4 weeks
  • Oral therapy:
    • First-Line Oral Therapy:
      • Terbinafine
      • Itraconazole
    • Second-Line Therapy:
      • Griseofulvin
      • For resistant Indian strains of mentagrophytes

Sporothrix schenckii (Option A) causes the disease sporotrichosis after entering the skin via trauma. The fungi cause lesions at the site of inoculation and are ulcerated with erythematous edges, unlike in the given scenario.

Mycobacterium leprae (Option B) causes leprosy, which presents as hypopigmented skin patches with sensory loss or thickened peripheral nerves. This is not apt for the given case.

Candida albicans (Option D) causes candidiasis, which is generally secondary to immune suppression, which can be local or systemic, including extremes of age. It may involve the oral cavity (thrush), genital areas like the vagina or penis, or other regions of the body. It does not present as in the given scenario.

questions.text: Which of the following is known as Dhobi's itch?
questions.solution:
Tinea cruris, also known as jock itch/Dhobi's itch is an infection involving the genital, pubic, perineal, and perianal skin caused by pathogenic fungi known as dermatophytes.

Tinea cruris

Causative Organisms

  • Caused by dermatophytes similar to those in tinea pedis.
  • Trichophyton rubrum - most common.
  • Others: . indotineae, T. interdigitale, and Epidermophyton floccosum.

Clinical Features

  • Itching is the main symptom.
  • Begins as red plaques with sharp, curved edges in the groin area, often extending down the thighs.
  • Scaling varies and can sometimes hide the inflammation.
  • Vesicles are uncommon; nodules forming a "beaded" margin are common in older lesions.
  • Tiny pustules may be visible on careful examination.
  • Central clearing is often seen but may be incomplete.
  • Satellite lesions (if present) are usually few and large.
  • The scrotum may be involved, but with less scaling and inflammation against a red background.

Treatment:

  • Recent-onset:
    • Topical terbinafine or imidazoles (2× daily for 2 weeks).
  • Chronic/extensive:
    • Oral terbinafine 250 mg/day (1-2 weeks), or
    • Itraconazole 100 mg/day (2-4 weeks).

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with an itchy rash on his thigh. He gave a history of using topical corticosteroids a few days back, which gave him temporary relief. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tinea incognito is a type of dermatophyte infection modified by corticosteroid (systemic or topical) and other immunosuppressive agents.

Tinea incognito

  • Ringworm infection altered by systemic or topical corticosteroids, often prescribed for another condition or misdiagnosed as eczema, is called tinea incognito due to its disguised appearance.

Pathophysiology:

  • Corticosteroids suppress local inflammation and immune response, masking typical ringworm signs.
  • They also reduce cell-mediated immunity, allowing fungal growth to continue unchecked.

Clinical Features

  • Patients often report initial relief from itching and redness.
  • Symptoms recur after stopping steroids, and reapplication brings temporary relief, creating a treatment cycle.
  • Presentation:
    • The characteristic raised, scaly border disappears.
    • Appearance includes nondescript nodules, brownish discolouration, and minimal inflammation.
    • On the face, it may mimic perioral dermatitis (papules and pustules); on the eyelids, it can resemble a stye.
    • Chronic use may cause skin atrophy, telangiectasia, and striae in the groins or underarms.
    • Even mild steroids (like 1% hydrocortisone) can significantly alter the presentation.

Management

  • Oral antifungals (e.g., terbinafine, itraconazole) are recommended rather than topical agents alone.
  • Continue low-potency topical steroids (e.g., 1% hydrocortisone) temporarily to ease symptoms while antifungals take effect.
  • Advise patients about possible symptom rebound and the importance of steroid discontinuation.
  • Arrange follow-up to confirm steroids have stopped and the infection is fully resolved.

Tinea corporis (Option A), commonly referred to as ringworm, is a superficial fungal infection of the skin caused by dermatophytes from the Trichophyton, Epidermophyton, or Microsporum genera. It typically presents with itching and may become extensive or merge into larger patches, particularly in individuals with weakened immune systems.

Tinea cruris (Options B) or jock itch, is a fungal infection affecting the skin of the groin, pubic region, perineum, and perianal area, caused by dermatophyte fungi. Patients typically present with an itchy rash localised to the groin area.

questions.text: Which of the following fungi causes ectothrix type Tinea capitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ectothrix type of Tinea capitis is caused by the fungus Microsporum canis.

Tinea capitis

  • Tinea capitis involves the invasion of the hair shafts by the dermatophyte M. canis.
  • This can be of 2 types:
    • Endothrix: Where the fungi affect the hair shaft - Trichophyton tonsurans(Option B)
    • Ectothrix: Where the fungi affect the outer sheath root - Microsporum canis

Ectothrix type Tinea capitis

  • Causative Organisms:
    • Commonly caused by Microsporum audouinii, M. canis, M. equinum, and M. ferrugineum.
    • Also seen with gypseum, M. fulvum, M. nanum, and M. vanbreuseghemii.
  • Features:
    • Grey patch: Grey, lustreless scaling.
  • Pathology:
    • Invasion Pattern:
      • Begins mid-follicle, with fungal hyphae invading the hair shaft.
      • Hyphae extend inward toward the hair bulb (intrapilary growth).
      • Extrapilary hyphae develop on the outer surface of the hair shaft, which grows outward.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Wood's Lamp Examination:
      • Characteristic fluorescence is seen with ectothrix infection, especially with Microsporum
      • Some species may not always fluoresce, but many do.

Epidermophyton floccosum (Option C) is a dermatophyte that causes diseases like tinea cruris, tinea pedis, tinea corporis, and onychomycosis. It is, however, not involved in causing ectothrix type Tinea corporis.

Trichophyton schoenleinii (Option D) is responsible for causing trichophytosis and favus (tinea favosa) of the scalp, not ectothrix tinea capitis

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with a mild, painful swelling over the scalp for 3 months. He gives a history of having a pet dog at home. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a kerion, a tender, boggy, inflamed mass, usually caused by an inflammatory response to tinea capitis.

  • Tinea capitis is an infection of the scalp hair caused by dermatophyte fungi such as Trichophyton and Microsporumspp.

Kerion

  • A kerion is the most severe inflammatory response pattern seen in tinea capitis.
  • Features:
    • It presents as a tender, boggy, inflamed mass on the scalp.
    • Remaining hairs are loose and may fall out easily (easy pluckability).
    • The lesion may discharge pus from hair follicles and sometimes form sinuses.
    • In rare cases, mycetoma-like grains may be observed.
    • Thick crusting and matting of nearby hairs are often present.
    • Regional lymph node enlargement may be seen.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Pustule formation is primarily due to the host's immune response to the fungal elements, not necessarily a bacterial cause.
  • Distribution
    • Lesions can be single or multiple.
    • Occasionally, a large confluent plaque may cover a significant area of the scalp.
  • Causative Organisms:
    • Most commonly caused by zoophilic fungi such as:
      • Trichophyton verrucosum
      • T. mentagrophytes
      • M. canis

Furuncle (Option A): A boil, or furuncle, is a painful, pus-filled swelling in the skin that resembles an enlarged yellow pimple that is caused by a bacterial infection. It tends to be more tender and inflamed than a regular pimple. This is however, not a result of fungal infection rather a bacterial infection.

Dissecting cellulitis (Option C): Also referred to as Hoffman's disease, it is an inflammatory skin condition that presents with perifollicular pustules, nodules, keloids, abscesses, and sinus tracts, eventually leading to scarring-related hair loss.

Abscess (Option D): An abscess is a confined accumulation of pus consisting of dead tissue, fluid, and immune cells, enclosed by a vascular, irregular inflammatory capsule. The adjacent soft tissue is often affected, showing varying levels of swelling and cellulitis. This is not the given scenario.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presented with a patch of partial alopecia on the scalp as shown. The disease is not caused by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The disease tinea capitis (ringworm of the scalp) is not caused by Epidermophyton floccosum. 

  • Epidermophyton floccosum is a type of filamentous fungus that primarily infects human skin and nails.
  • Being anthropophilic, it is responsible for conditions like tinea pedis, tinea cruris, tinea corporis, and onychomycosis.
  • Tinea capitis is caused by dermatophytes of the Trichophyton and Microsporum species only.

questions.text: A farmer presented with lesions as shown in the image. He says that he developed an initial lesion after a small injury to his foot, which was a nodule and painless. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image depicts Mycetoma, a chronic granulomatous infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, most commonly affecting the foot. It is characterised by swelling, draining sinuses, and the discharge of grains.

Mycetoma

  • Mycetoma is a chronic, localised infection caused by fungi (eumycetoma) or actinomycetes (actinomycetoma).
  • Characterised by the formation of grains (clusters of the organisms) within abscesses.
  • Leads to destruction of skin, subcutaneous tissues, and bones.
  • Grains are discharged through sinus tracts on the skin.

Clinical Features:

  • Site & Early Lesion:
    • Most commonly affects the feet and lower legs due to trauma exposure, though other body parts can be involved.
    • The initial lesion is a firm, painless nodule.
  • Progression:
    • Nodules progress to papules/pustules, which rupture to form draining sinuses.
    • The area becomes hardened and swollen, often painless despite advanced disease.
    • In advanced mycetoma, multiple sinuses discharge pus or seropurulent fluid.
    • The infection may spread to bones and joints, causing periostitis, osteomyelitis, or arthritis.
    • Progressive bone destruction can lead to severe deformities over time.
  • Triad:
    • Tumefaction (painless, firm subcutaneous swelling)
    • Draining sinuses
    • Pus discharge with granules

Management:

  • First-Line Treatment
    • Actinomycetoma:
      • Option 1: Dapsone + Streptomycin or Rifampicin
      • Option 2: Co-trimoxazole + Streptomycin or Rifampicin
    • Eumycetoma:
      • Azole antifungals (e.g. Itraconazole)
      • Followed by surgical removal of the remaining lesions
  • Second-Line Treatment
    • Radical surgery for cases not responding to medical therapy

Phaeohyphomycosis (Option B) is a term used for infections caused by a diverse group of fungi known as dematiaceous or melanised fungi. These organisms are identified by the presence of melanin in their cell walls, which is believed to contribute to their pathogenicity or virulence.

Sporotrichosis (Option C), caused by Sporothrix schenckii, is typically acquired through direct contact with contaminated soil, plants, or organic material. The infection usually begins as red, raised papulonodular lesions, which may appear smooth or warty and often spread along the lymphatic vessels.

Chromoblastomycosis (Option D) is a long-standing granulomatous infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissues caused by pigmented fungi. It typically begins as a pink or red spot or bump and may progress to form verrucous papules, nodules, scaly plaques, ulcerated or cauliflower-like growths, and scar-like plaques

questions.text: A 50-year-old farmer presents with the lesions on his foot as shown. The lesions have developed over a few years and initially looked like warty papules. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows chromoblastomycosis, a chronic fungal infection involving skin and subcutaneous tissues characterised by slow-growing, raised (exophytic) lesions, most commonly on feet and legs.

Chromoblastomycosis

  • Chronic fungal infection involving skin and subcutaneous tissues.
  • Caused by pigmented fungi that form thick-walled sclerotic (muriform) bodies in tissues.

Histopathology:

  • Characteristic muriform (sclerotic) cells: Thick-walled, brown, and divided by transverse and longitudinal septa, often found within giant cells.
  • These sclerotic cells are also known as medlar bodies or copper-penny bodies.

Clinical Features:

  • Typically occurs on exposed body parts: feet, legs, arms, face, and neck.
  • The disease progresses very slowly, often over several years.
  • Presentation:
    • Begins as a warty papule that gradually enlarges into a hypertrophic plaque.
    • Lesions are usually painless, but secondary infection can cause itching or discomfort.
    • Satellite lesions may develop due to scratching.
    • Lymphatic spread to nearby skin areas may occur.

Management

  • First-Line Treatment
    • Itraconazole 200 mg daily or Terbinafine 250 mg daily
    • Flucytosine can be used alone or combined with amphotericin B, but solo use may lead to drug resistance.
  • Second-Line
    • Cryotherapy or
    • Daily heat application using gel packs (comfortable temperature); effective over 2–3 months.
    • Surgical excision is only for small, well-defined lesions, and should be paired with antifungal therapy.
    • Photodynamic therapy has shown benefit in selected cases.

The infection usually begins as red, raised papulonodular lesions, which may appear smooth or warty and often spread along the lymphatic vessels

questions.text: A HIV positive adult male with hilar lymphadenopathy and lung involvement presented with lesions on the face as shown. CBNAAT was negative. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical picture in this HIV-positive adult male with hilar lymphadenopathy, lung involvement, and cutaneous facial lesions, along with a negative CBNAAT, is suggestive of disseminated histoplasmosis, especially given his immunocompromised status.

Histoplasmosis

  • Histoplasmosis is a systemic fungal infection caused by Histoplasma capsulatum.
  • It primarily affects the lungs, usually through inhalation of spores, and may be asymptomatic or mild.
  • The fungus is intracellular, often spreading to the reticuloendothelial system (spleen, liver, bone marrow, CNS), particularly in immunocompromised individuals such as those with HIV/AIDS.
  • In advanced or disseminated disease, cutaneous lesions may develop.

Skin Involvement:

  • Cutaneous lesions are more common in immunocompromised patients, especially those with AIDS.
  • Lesions can arise from hematogenous spread following pulmonary infection.
  • In rare cases, primary cutaneous infection can occur via direct inoculation (e.g., lab accidents), presenting as localized ulcers or granulomas.
  • Skin lesions may include:
    • Papules
    • Nodules
    • Ulcers
    • Granulomas
    • Abscesses
    • Fistulae
    • Scars
    • Pigmentary changes
  • Some lesions may mimic cellulitis, especially in severely immunosuppressed patients.
  • Secondary skin involvement may also occur in patients with underlying bone involvement.

Molluscum contagiosum (Option B) Molluscum contagiosum, commonly known as water warts, is a non-cancerous skin infection. The characteristic lesions are round, dome-shaped, and have a pink to purplish hue, which is not the given scenario.

Cryptococcosis (Option C) is a systemic illness, especially in the immunocompromise,d caused by the fungus Cryptococcus, which enters via inhalation. The clinical manifestations however, of this condition are fever, headache, malaise, photophobia and neck stiffness, as meningoencephalitis is most commonly caused by it.

Disseminated tuberculosis (Option D) is not a possible diagnosis since the patient has a CBNAAT negative report.

questions.text:
Which of the following infections resembles the given pattern?

  1. Leishmaniasis
  2. Sporotrichosis
  3. M.marinum infection
  4. None of the above
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lesions of sporotrichosis can resemble the granulomatous lesions of leishmaniasis and Mycobacterium marinum (fish-tank granuloma).

Sporotrichosis

  • Fungal infection caused by Sporothrix species, affecting the skin and sometimes spreading systemically.
  • Occurs in both acute and chronic forms.

Pathology

  • The fungus causes granulomatous inflammation with foci of neutrophils.
  • Yeast forms (3-5 μm) appear as cigar-shaped or oval bodies in tissues.
  • May be surrounded by eosinophilic material, forming asteroid bodies.

Clinical Features

  • Cutaneous Sporotrichosis:
    • Lymphangitic Form (most common):
      • Follows skin trauma with spore implantation.
      • Initial nodule or pustule ulcerates.
      • Lymphatic spread leads to a chain of nodules along draining lymphatics.
      • Nodules ulcerate with thin purulent discharge.
      • Lesions may heal spontaneously; systemic symptoms are uncommon.
    • Fixed Form (localised):
      • Lesions are confined to the inoculation site.
      • May appear as: Acneiform papules, nodules, or verrucous/ ulcerated plaques.
      • It may resemble leishmaniasis or cutaneous TB.
      • Often seen in patients with stronger immunity.
  • Systemic/Disseminated Sporotrichosis:
    • Rare; seen in immunocompromised patients.
    • Lesions may mimic mycetoma or chronic ulcers.
    • S. brasiliensis infections can be extensive, longer to treat, and accompanied by erythema nodosum/multiforme and arthralgia.

Differential Diagnosis:

  • Mycobacterial infections (especially Mycobacterium marinum).
  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis
  • Other granulomatous infections have with similar appearance.
  • Important to consider the history of trauma or inoculation in suspect cases.
